title: Chord Progressions
description: Learn the most popular chord progressions in music — I-V-vi-IV and I-vi-IV-V.

steps.title: What is a Chord Progression?
steps.description:
A chord progression is a sequence of chords played in order. In the key of C major, the chords are numbered with Roman numerals:

• I = C (major)
• ii = Dm (minor)
• iii = Em (minor)
• IV = F (major)
• V = G (major)
• vi = Am (minor)
• vii° = Bdim

Most pop songs use just 3-4 of these chords!

steps.title: The 'Four Chord Song'
steps.description: The I-V-vi-IV progression (C-G-Am-F) is the most used chord progression in pop music. Songs like 'Let It Be', 'No Woman No Cry', 'With or Without You', and hundreds more use this exact sequence.

steps.title: Step 1: Play C (I)
steps.description: Start the progression with C major — the 'home' chord.

steps.title: Step 2: Play G (V)
steps.description: Move to G major — the dominant chord.

steps.title: Step 3: Play Am (vi)
steps.description: Now A minor — the relative minor. This gives the progression its emotional contrast.

steps.title: Step 4: Play F (IV)
steps.description: Finish with F major — the subdominant. Then the progression loops back to C.

steps.title: The '50s Progression'
steps.description: The I-vi-IV-V progression (C-Am-F-G) is another classic. It was hugely popular in the 1950s and 60s ('Stand By Me', 'Earth Angel'). It starts the same but puts the minor chord second, creating a different emotional arc.
